text:
China has toughness and discipline on its side in its showdown with America. But the rigidity of China’s one-party system, and its horror of exposing Xi Jinping to embarrassment, makes dealing with Trumpian chaos a nightmare. My column, “The Telegram”
economist.com/internationa...
from The Economist

The latest Trumplaw emergency at SCOTUS is about the president's power to remove agency officials. It's a big deal. Here's my @economist.com analysis w/ insights from @williambaude.bsky.social , @stevevladeck.bsky.social and Sai Prakash www.economist.com/united-state...

Amid Donald Trump’s trade war tumult, lots of smart insiders in Washington, Beijing and other capitals still think he has ambitions to cut deals. And some of those deals could be hugely disruptive to the world order. My column, “The Telegram”
economist.com/internationa...
from The Economist

The thing about Europe: it's the actual land of the free now.

Whatever problems Europe has - and it has plenty - it is looking pretty damn good by comparison these days.

My Charlemagne this week

www.economist.com/europe/2025/...

Donald Trump has replaced the old certainties that underpinned the world economy with extraordinary levels of volatility and confusion.

Some of the chaos may have abated for now. But it will take a very long time to rebuild what has been lost econ.st/4i6Z4Vx

The rare good-ish news story on the British economy—why Britain is surprisingly well-insulated from a tariff crash, at least compared to most of its peers:

Part, but not all of the answer is in quite how much (un-tariffed) services dominate British exports.

Link: www.economist.com/britain/202...

DOGE’s cuts have put vital gov't data at risk. Amid the chaos of Trump’s second term, it’s easy to miss—but the federal surveys we use to understand everything from the economy to maternal mortality to healthcare costs are under threat. My piece this week: www.economist.com/united-state...

China has a big beautiful opportunity. Xi Jinping’s paranoid nationalism used to seem like dystopian hyperbole. Now that Donald Trump is committing such wanton self-harm and general destruction, it looks ahead of its time econ.st/3E4l0mp

Get ready for a slew of lawsuits against Trump's tariffs. There's a strong case he does not have the authority to impose them. But there are wrinkles galore, explored in my latest @economist.com, with insights from @nbagley.bsky.social and Alan Morrison. www.economist.com/united-state...

Our forecast of the Canadian election is live 📈🇨🇦

We give the Liberal Party an 83% chance of winning the most seats on 28th April

www.economist.com/interactive/...

Donald Trump has committed the most profound, harmful and unnecessary economic error in the modern era. Almost everything he said—on history, economics and the technicalities of trade—was utterly deluded econ.st/3YbbFjq

Quick 🧵 with more than you'll want to know on the OBR's trend productivity estimate—a number that could blow up Labour's next budget

To illustrate the scale: nudging it down by 0.25 percentage points would ~fully offset the headroom opened by raising employer NICs last year

1/

Donald Trump’s views on allies are being urgently debated by China’s rulers. Is he ditching Europe and Canada to focus on China - as US hawks claim - or will he ditch Asian allies too and pull back from the world? My column, The Telegram, from Beijing and Shanghai
economist.com/internationa...
Israel’s expansionism is a danger to others—and itself econ.st/3Rn8Tnm
Is Elon Musk remaking America’s government, or breaking it? There are three possible outcomes for DOGE econ.st/42bGqGf

The British government says it's being bold on driving economic growth. If it truly thinks so, that is only because of a lack of ambition and imagination.

My leader taking stock of Labour's economic agenda:
➡️ www.economist.com/leaders/2025...

My analysis for @economist.com of the Spring Statement just went up. Highlights:
— Yesterday's brouhaha was entirely avoidable
— Britain remains fiscally rickety
— Eyes are on the next budget, where another round of tax rises now looks likely

(More⬇️)

www.economist.com/britain/2025...

In a turbulent, Trumpian world, expect many Western countries to decide that confronting China over values or geopolitics is a luxury they can ill afford. That doesn’t mean relations will be smooth-huge tensions over trade remain. My column, The Telegram, from Beijing
economist.com/internationa...
The exchange will only heighten alarm in Europe. It will stoke fears that America could fast turn from a protector into something more like a predator econ.st/4kYCTDL

“Turkey is nearing a point of no return. Only last week, its government was still what political scientists call a competitive authoritarian regime…But on March 19th police detained Mr Imamoglu, who has emerged as Mr Erdogan’s strongest rival. What remains is close to naked autocracy.”

Back to work after a week off and wanted to belatedly share thoughts on America's Middle East policy after a trip to DC this month. The first of which is that Trump has a skeleton crew: if personnel is policy, there's almost no policy because there are almost no personnel. 🧵
I had a sneak peek at some data which is being published by Meta today, showing that Britain is less divided by class than you might expect: www.economist.com/britain/2025...

I raised the prospect that the Fed's swap lines might not be there during the next financial crisis in this column on the breakdown of international economic cooperation in the 1930s.

It is not the economic impact of tariffs that is most worrying www.economist.com/finance-and-...
The market value of Tesla has fallen by roughly half since December. Competition is revving up for the carmaker. But it is not the only thing Elon Musk should be worried about econ.st/4iWTRRa
The idea of upgrading humans holds plenty of promise. Realising it will mean driving out the cranks and bringing the technology into the mainstream econ.st/41Oftbn

I wrote this week on the PLA's new barge-bridge  vessels, which could unlock significant new capacity for China to sustain & support any invasion of Taiwan, allowing it to deliver a greater quantity of follow-on forces to the island without seizing a port. www.economist.com/china/2025/0...
Our data team looked at first names and what they reveal, with some fascinating graphics. Have a look. 👇 www.economist.com/interactive/...

How far could Xi Jinping go to resist the Panama Canal port deal? For this week's Economist, I parse the latest signs of Chinese displeasure at BlackRock's planned purchase of 2 Panama ports and 41 others from Hong Kong-based CK Hutchison www.economist.com/china/2025/0...

Wrote about Zoe, and how it exemplifies the modern wellness industry. 

My own theory -- which I'd like to see them test -- is that personalised recommendations are effective at changing behaviour because we all like to feel special. 

www.economist.com/britain/2025...

The Five Eyes spy pact is the world's most successful SIGINT (or signals intelligence) alliance in history. Is Donald Trump putting it at risk?
This week in the International pages of @economist.com we have a crunchy look at how it works by @shashj.bsky.social 
www.economist.com/internationa...
The idea of upgrading humans holds plenty of promise. Realising it will mean driving out the cranks and bringing the technology into the mainstream econ.st/4iibACB

On paper, the modern refugee system has roots in a set of moral certainties that governments signed up to after WW2. Actually the history of the Geneva refugee convention and the asylum system is much messier and more political than that. My column TheTelegram 1/2

economist.com/internationa...

For decades Alzheimer’s research has been marred by disappointment—existing drugs only slow the disease. Now an old idea, once dismissed as fringe, is making a comeback. If it’s right, millions of cases could be prevented using medicines we already have...

www.economist.com/science-and-...

Come for the chart, stay for the unnecessary autobiographical detour— I wrote Blighty, @economist.com newsletter on Britain this week.

Read (and indeed subscribe) here: www.economist.com/britain/202...

Quick take on Labour’s announcements today to tacke worklessness:
— After years of dithering by multiple governments, any action is welcome
— The rest of Labour’s economic agenda may well sabotage this effort

More in my @economist.com leader:
www.economist.com/leaders/202...

Amid a flurry of book reviews calling the Abundance liberals too neoliberal, I've—valiantly—taken the other side to encourage them to lean further in a markets-y direction.

My review for @economist.com of Abundance and Why Nothing Works ⬇️

www.economist.com/finance-and-...

Everything you need to know about the European nuclear deterrence debate, and what options really lie ahead for Macron, Starmer, Merz, Tusk and other Europeans. By my colleague @shashj.bsky.social 

www.economist.com/internationa...

About three quarters of aid spending goes on something that doesn't work: trying to make poor countries rich by spending money. Only a quarter is humanitarian relief and health funding

www.economist.com/finance-and-...

www.economist.com/leaders/2025... Dismissing Manus by noting that it's just an assemblage of off-the-shelf models and tools misses the point: now that you can push the frontier by assembling off the shelf models and tools, the "AI safety" conversation needs to change rapidly
DeepSeek is free, fast and still best in class. Geopolitics and censorship are making potential users cautious - but not putting them off entirely

If the peace deal collapses, fighting could quickly engulf the country. Worse still, it could merge with Sudan’s civil war across the border 👇

www.economist.com/middle-east-...

The new economics of nativism
www.economist.com/finance-and-...

The Economist's cover story this week is essentially a guide for how Europe could wage economic war on America if needed. Which for a publication as Atlantacist as us is uh, something
www.economist.com/briefing/202...
From The Economist
There is no point whingeing about Donald Trump’s frenetic foreign policy. America’s bullied allies need to toughen up econ.st/3FwcIEb

Britain's rise in worklessness has been five-year slow-motion disaster. Not far off a million more people are out of work and not looking, versus 2019.

I wrote a chunky piece on this for @economist.com, but wanted to draw out a few specific bits here (🧵)

www.economist.com/britain/202...

In 2024, Russia seized less than half a percent of Ukrainian land at the cost of about 100,000 lives, new estimates of casualties and my calculations suggest. My take on the latest data:
www.economist.com/graphic-deta...

Our poll of Ukraine is now in (N=1000). Mr Zelensky approval at >70%, very few want elections before peace. But also suggests 58% will not want Ukraine to concede territory, and that many also expect the war to end within the year ->
www.economist.com/europe/2025/... by  @olliecarroll.bsky.social

Britain has been quietly making significant progress in women's representation across business and politics. 
Data for all 29 OECD countries in our annual glass-ceiling index 👇
www.economist.com/graphic-deta...

Which countries are most exposed to cuts to US foreign aid? Those who rely heavily on health funding, and which are least able to replace this. 

www.economist.com/graphic-deta...

“The talks in Jeddah lasted several hours. According to participants, the Ukrainians opened with Zelensky’s idea for partial ceasefire. The Americans countered with the idea of a complete ceasefire…an initial 30 days, renewable if both combatants agree” www.economist.com/europe/2025/...

Can Friedrich Merz get Europe out of its funk?

My Charlemagne this week on the budding Merz-mentum (sorry) changing the mood in the EU.

www.economist.com/europe/2025/...

“We need to be clear: while the American people may still be our friends, the Trump administration is no longer our ally”

François Hollande’s guest essay in @economist.com 

economist.com/by-invitatio...

Governments worldwide are bracing for Donald Trump’s transactional, “show me the money” approach to statecraft to become a global norm, as old rules and institutions crumble. A sobering edition of The Telegram, reported from D.C. and NYC 
economist.com/internationa...
from The Economist
It has been a transformative week for Sir Keir Starmer. The prime minister has sketched a new role for Britain in the world—but he must get radical at home, too econ.st/3XwW1P8
Are the Liberals back? I took a look at their polling surge with our Canada correspondent, Rob Russo: www.economist.com/the-americas...

Beauty routines with a side of Trump, raw milk lattes and “Make America Hot Again” parties: in the lucrative world of fashion and lifestyle influencing, conservatism is gaining clout. For this week's issue of @economist.com, I met the women giving MAGA a makeover www.economist.com/united-state...
Foreign aid’s demise will be brutal and chaotic. But it offers an opportunity to rethink an inefficient system that has long needed an overhaul econ.st/4kqbjyW
Investors, consumers and companies are showing the first signs of souring on Donald Trump’s vision. With his aggressive and erratic protectionism, he is playing with fire econ.st/41tx87X
After the AfD's surge on Sunday, far right parties are the most voted-for of any grouping in Europe, for the first time in history: www.economist.com/graphic-deta...

In the corridors of political Kyiv, officials are largely stunned by the ferocity of the American treatment towards their leader.

Among those strategising about what to do next, the key question is why did it happen? Two main theories are circulating econ.st/43hV2WP

Can Europe confront Vladimir Putin’s Russia on its own? 
This is the question we asked in this week's International pages of @economist.com 
 
The answer is grim. A short 🧵

I wrote about the latest Democracy index from EIU. 2024 was a great year for polling-booth manufacturers, but less so for global democracy

www.economist.com/interactive/...

Israel and Hamas both seem willing to extend the Gaza ceasefire by a few weeks. But buying more time for phase-two talks does not mean those talks will succeed: they will run up against a familiar problem, that both sides have incompatible demands. www.economist.com/middle-east-...

Good piece by Mark Greenblatt, one of the fired inspector generals, in this week's "By Invitation" section of The Economist, on why the firing of IGs is so worrying: 

Donald Trump should not replace us with his stooges, warns a fired inspector-general
www.economist.com/by-invitatio...

Did some of the maths in this week's The @economist.com on EU defence spending and Ukraine aid if America withdraws. 

Doable, but requires putting a lot of money on the table. www.economist.com/europe/2025/...
If you want a good life, inheriting is becoming nearly as important as working. That is dangerous for capitalism and society econ.st/3QDUfYu
A mafia-like struggle for global power has begun, with rules that do not suit America. Other countries are already planning for a lawless era econ.st/3DbeFFe

Some sad news to share: John Parker, one of The Economist’s finest correspondents, has died at the age of 70.

At a time of global upheaval the world has lost one of the people best able to interpret momentous change. We remember his lengthy career econ.st/4kjEOm4

Europe is desperately–and justifiably–keen to be a party to Ukraine peace talks.

In practice it will be allowed ONE envoy to face off against Trump and Putin.

Who should it be?
Charlemagne this week considers the main candidates. Should it be Costa? Macron? Tusk?

www.economist.com/europe/2025/...

No, Pres Trump wooing Putin is not the same as Nixon going to China. My column on Trumpworld’s claims that their hero is about to split Russia from China. Actually, the main split is between the U.S. and western allies
www.economist.com/internationa...
from The Economist

Trimming the headcount of federal employees, as Elon Musk wants to do, is unlikely to save much money. Civilian payroll costs account for just 4% of the $7trn the government spends each year econ.st/3CS39yA

Governments in the Sahel are leading a new wave of resource nationalism in Africa. But there is more pragmatism than meets the eye 

My latest from Mali, with John Mcdermott in Cape Town 

www.economist.com/middle-east-...

Here’s our piece on the state of play in the Ukraine-US mineral “deal”. Tldr: the American proposal is unclear, punitive and makes no sense. There are perfectly good ways for Ukraine to reward America for support by letting it exploit mineral deposits. This is not one of them.

The Americans called it a “transaction of love.” The Ukrainian officials I spoke to called it differently: “not negotiation, but extortion”.

www.economist.com/europe/2025/...

Ukrainian officials say their encounters with Donald Trump’s team are so confusing that they have been watching documentaries for clues about his negotiation style. There have been three versions of a deal, considered “bad”, “better” and “disastrous” econ.st/3XhvSno

Whatever the final result, it is not an outcome that will please those that had hoped desperately for political clarity in a country that has long been lacking it. Neither party hoping to govern can be satisfied econ.st/4b9JM0B

One of the more alarming announcements, given the Trump administration’s trashing of conventions across the federal government, was the dismissal of the most senior lawyers of the army, navy and air force econ.st/41CNv3H

Ventured to Kansas this week to write about how Trump’s funding cuts are already hurting some of his biggest supporters: farmers
www.economist.com/united-state...

My piece this week on the dilemma facing countries like Egypt and Jordan. For decades, America saw them as linchpins of regional stability. But now the region's status quo has been upended, and being a force for inertia is no longer seen as a merit. www.economist.com/middle-east-...

To reflect the momentous events of the past week we designed two covers featuring Donald Trump.

One explains how Europe must respond as he and Vladimir Putin smash the post-war order econ.st/41vGi5q

The other considers the power of the president econ.st/4gRbzUD

“Once you go there, you won’t go back”

I followed the black market in human growth hormone for @economist.com's The Weekend Intelligence. I met doctors, users and drug dealers to understand our quest to optimise ourselves, and what it can ultimately cost. 

www.economist.com/podcasts/202...

Some people just imprint themselves on your memory, even after one meeting. Pableaux Johnson did that for me, and it was an honour to remember him in our pages this week: www.economist.com/obituary/202...
My Charlemagne on the week to end all weeks in Europe. We are one month down, 47 to go of the Trump presidency. Will we be able to withstand it? www.economist.com/europe/2025/...

How far can knife crime be treated as a problem of supply? My latest story is on a peculiarly British problem and what is and isn't in the government's strategy for curbing it. (Also tested the much-trailed round-tipped knives: they are surprisingly good) www.economist.com/britain/2025...
Great job opening at The Economist: we're looking for an economics correspondent to cover Britain. No journalistic experience necessary. www.economist.com/britain/2025...
Europe has had its bleakest week since the fall of the Iron Curtain. This is how it must respond to the threat posed by Donald Trump and Vladimir Putin econ.st/4gSbyQp
America is fated to wage a titanic struggle over the power of the president econ.st/4kb0dOg

Australia has been brooding for years about its dependency on America for security and China for prosperity. That angst may just stand Australia in good stead in a lonelier, harsher world. An edition of The Telegram reported from Sydney, Canberra and Perth

www.economist.com/internationa...
If Friedrich Merz becomes Germany’s chancellor he will need a mandate for sweeping change. So far, he has been too timid to ask for one econ.st/42SJskJ

The big question after reading Get In: Is Sir Keir Starmer a chump? 
www.economist.com/britain/2025...

On the ageing of London, which I think reveals the city's strengths as well as its problems
www.economist.com/britain/2025...
The last thing that Indonesia’s navy needs is an aircraft carrier. Our Banyan this week:

The Economist's obituary this week is of Donald Shoup. As a rule, our brilliant obits editor, Ann Wroe, avoids writing about economists for the obit pages, figuring there's enough of them in the rest of the paper. Shoup was interesting enough to deserve a place 
www.economist.com/obituary/202...
How are Germans planning to vote? I took a look, with five charts and a bunch of data 🇩🇪📈
Will Donald Trump and Elon Musk wreck the Pentagon or reform it? America’s security depends upon their success econ.st/4hBgudp

The impact of the latest round of tariffs on US imports from China depends on what the alternatives are. If you thought most of these imported goods are easy to get from elsewhere, I'd think again 
www.economist.com/graphic-deta...

Wrote about the Ox-Cam Arc. Levers that could raise growth materially and quickly don't come easier than this. And Labour can pull it. 
www.economist.com/britain/2025...

My year-long investigation into the multibillion dollar world of online scams is out today  — on the cover of The Economist and in my new 8-part podcast series, Scam Inc

Read the article: bit.ly/scam-inc
Listen to the podcast: econ.st/3CFzGaL

I spent the last two days speaking w researchers and activists doing some of the most groundbreaking work on human rights in China. Many are facing pay cuts, layoffs, and total shutdown after the sudden freeze in US foreign aid
www.economist.com/china/2025/0...

Taiwan's armed forces have a Chinese spy problem. Prosecutions for Chinese espionage have jumped fourfold in the last 4 years. 2/3 of alleged spies last year were current or retired military personnel. China is also using new tactics to recruit younger collaborators
www.economist.com/asia/2025/02...
